lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
Welcome! React is a JavaScript library for creating web apps called single-page applications.

Single-page applications load as a single web page and dynamically update parts as you interact with it.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
React simplifies the development of web apps by allowing us to break code into reusable components.

In a music app, the song display cards can be a reusable component for each song in the playlist, making it easy to showcase a large number.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
You can picture those components as reusable blocks of code like bricks that you can use to build your application.

Let's look at a simple example, which returns Welcome to React.

Make sure to pick return, followed by "Welcome to React".

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
A component in React is just a function that returns something you want to show on the screen, like the message Hello, world.

Make sure to pick function, followed by return.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, we usually create components using the modern ES6 syntax for creating functions.

However, we can use any way of creating a function.

Make sure to pick = () =>, followed by function.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
From now on, we'll use the ES6 syntax for writing components. Weâ€™ll stick with the newer one because itâ€™s shorter and more modern.

If you see the old style somewhere, itâ€™s still perfectly fine to use.

Make sure to pick const followed by Welcome and then =, (), =>.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Think of a component like a recipe: it tells React what to "cook" (or display), and you can reuse that recipe whenever you need it.

Whatever we return will be displayed once the component is rendered.

Make sure to pick return, followed by "I'll be displayed", and finally ;.

Another way to think about a component is as custom HTML tags with superpowers.

The function's name defines the component, allowing you to reuse it just like an HTML tag but with added functionality and flexibility.

Make sure to pick MyComponent.

lessons.title: 3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Typically components start with an uppercase letter so that we can tell them apart from regular HTML tags.

Unlike normal JavaScript functions, React components are capitalized.

Make sure to pick MyComponent.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, a component doesnâ€™t just return plain text. It can return HTML, too.

We can create a component that returns an HTML heading with a certain text.

Make sure to pick <h1>, followed by Hello, world, and finally </h1>.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
What we see here is JSX, which looks like HTML but isnâ€™t. JSX is a special syntax that React uses to write HTML-like code inside JavaScript.

Construct an h1 tag as you would in plain HTML.

Make sure to pick <, followed by h1, and finally >.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
Despite JSX not being real HTML, JSX looks and feels like HTML. It works similarly, so if you know HTML, JSX will be familiar to you.

React converts JSX into real HTML, so your browser can understand and display it just like normal HTML.

Make sure to pick <p>, followed by Welcome, and finally </p>.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this component return?

It returns the biggest heading HelloIt returns plain text Hello

It returns the biggest heading Hello.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create the JSX to render a paragraph.

Make sure to pick <p>, followed by I am 52 years old, and finally </p>.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this component?

The component should be capitalizedNothing, this is a valid React component

The component should be capitalized.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy  - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finish the React code to create a component that returns an h1 element.

Make sure to pick const followed by GreetingComponent and then (), return.

lessons.title: Lesson #16
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the building block of a React app called?

ComponentsFunctions

Make sure to pick Components.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
Ensure the react component returns JSX to render a p tag.

Make sure to type return.

lessons.title: Lesson #17
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do you create a React component?

You create a React component by writing a JavaScript function that returns JSXYou create a React component by writing HTML directly in your JavaScript file

You create a React component by writing a JavaScript function that returns JSX.

lessons.title: Lesson #18
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is JSX?

JSX is a syntax that looks like HTML but is actually JavaScript
JSX is a special type of HTML used only in React

JSX is a syntax that looks like HTML but is actually JavaScript
.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent: We already know how to create a component. The next step is to render it.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
React generates and then inserts HTML into our webpage's preexisting HTML container, like a div element.

Add a div with its ID set to "root" to our page.

Make sure to pick div, followed by id="root", and finally div.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
As a next step, we need to link to our JavaScript file. When using React, typically, we do that within the head element.

Inside the head element, link to the file called index.js.

Make sure to pick src, followed by =, and finally "./index.js".

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
By specifying type="module" in the <script> tag, we tell the browser that we'll use features like imports and exports.

Itâ€™s required for React to work correctly.

Make sure to pick type, followed by =, and finally "module".

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Thatâ€™s it! When working with React, we typically only need a very basic HTML page.

React will render the components we add inside the div element with the ID "root" and replace the loading placeholder.

Make sure to pick <div id="root">, followed by loading, and finally </div>.

lessons.title: Lesson #1 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
After setting up the basic HTML code, we switch to our index.jsx file to work on the React code.

In the HTML file, we reference our React file as index.js, but the file ends in .jsx because it contains both JavaScript and HTML-like JSX.

Make sure to pick return followed by <h1> and then Hello, React, </h1>.

lessons.title: Lesson #1 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To make React work as expected, we need to import the React package into your JavaScript file.

Import React from the "react" package.

Make sure to pick import followed by React and then from, "react".

lessons.title: Lesson #1 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Next, we import the createRoot function from the react-dom/client package, which can render our React components.

This function allows us to initialize a root in the DOM, where React can efficiently manage and render its components.

Make sure to pick { createRoot }, followed by "react-dom/client".

lessons.title: Lesson #1 -  - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Before using the createRoot function, we need an HTML element as the basis for that root.

Use document.getElementById to get the div element with the ID "root".

Make sure to pick document, followed by .getElementById, and finally "root".

lessons.title: Lesson #1 -  - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now, we can call the createRoot function and pass the reference to the div element as the parameter.

We save the returned value in a variable called root, which gives us control over rendering components within the specified DOM element.

Make sure to pick createRoot, followed by rootElement.

lessons.title: Lesson #1 -  - Copy -
lessons.interactiveContent:
To render our component, we call the render function on the newly created root object.

Make sure to pick root, followed by .render(), and finally ;.

lessons.title: Lesson #1 -  - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Last but not least, we need to pass the component we want to render as an argument to the function.

We need to wrap the component's name in angular brackets <>, like <MyComponent />, to render it in JSX.

Make sure to pick < followed by MyComponent and then /, >.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
React replaces the loading text inside the root element with the content from the MyComponent component, displaying Hello, React.

And just like that, you have your first fully functional React app!

Make sure to pick <div id="root">, followed by loading, and finally </div>.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why do we need to import createRoot?

We import createRoot to set up the place where React will render our componentWe import createRoot because it automatically renders the entire webpage

We import createRoot to set up the place where React will render our component.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a div element with an id property set to "root" to serve as the container for our React code.

Make sure to pick <div id="root">, followed by </div>.

lessons.title: Lesson #16
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does root.render do?

It takes the component and displays it inside the root elementIt adds event listeners to the component

It takes the component and displays it inside the root element.

lessons.title: Lesson #1 -  - Copy -  - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use document.getElementById to get the div element with the ID "root".

Make sure to pick document, followed by .getElementById, and finally "root".

lessons.title: Lesson #18
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the output of this code?

The code displays Hi there in an h1 tagThe code displays Hi there in an p tag

The code displays Hi there in an h1 tag.

lessons.title: Lesson #19
lessons.interactiveContent:
Put together the <script> tag to load the index.js file and ensure React renders as expected.

Make sure to pick script followed by type and then src, script.

lessons.title: Lesson #19 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use index.js instead of index.jsx because JSX is just syntax that gets translated into regular JavaScript during the build process.

The build process converts JSX into JavaScript so the browser can understand and run the code.

Make sure to pick .js.

lessons.title: Lesson #20
lessons.interactiveContent:
Put together the correct JSX syntax to render the component.

Make sure to pick < followed by MyComponent and then /, >.
